posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Hi Asturo
You combine 3 classes that all benefit from having many levels.
Elf has none of them as favored class and will suffer an xp penalty unless you keep Ranger and Cleric levels close. But if you do that, both classes will suffer because they both get better with many levels.
Ranger 9 is often used for the dual wield feats. The lvl 9 animal companion will be far to weak when you level up. Ranger has the class skills to qualify early for Assassin, so those two classes match well.
Cleric is a caster and a self buffer class. With only 10 levels you cannot rely on the buffs because they are so easily dispelled by enamy casters. Many of the Cleric buffs "mature" at lvl 15, and many builders consider 15 levels of Cleric as a minimum in a self buffer build. The spells of a low level Cleric will be easily resisted, so don't count on attack spells with such a build. Turn undead will also be too weak.
The only reason you give for not taking assassin to near 30 levels is that you want to make room for the other classes, and that can be fair enough if you want another focus than the Death attack.
When you answer what you want the character to be good at, I read things like; back up plan, semi good, and a lot of different things and I hardly see a focus. 

There are several ways to build versatile characters. But you still need to focus on how the character can survive when the going gets tough.
The three classes you have chosen all have great potential. If you want an optimized build, or something close: Drop elf if you want both cleric and ranger. If you want Elf: Go heavy on Cleric with Assassin as a minor tumble class. You may also go light on Ranger and heavy on Assassin for Dual wield and a strong Death attack, or heavy on Ranger for a high bonus vs FE and BoE and light on Assassin for tumble and HIPS. But all of that probably means starting a new character.

The elven Ranger 9/ Cleric 10/ Assassin 21 is not ideal, but possible to play. HIPS helps. But both Cleric spell casting and Assassin Death attack and bonus feats would benefit greatly from more levels.

posts.content:
I'll have a proper look when I get a chance, Asturo (hope you don't mind the abbreviation).

I will say that I have every admiration for your commitment to design on the hoof, but it does contain certain potential pitfalls. Allocating skills can be a nightmare if you don't know when you have to save them or how many you want/need by the end - and how many you'll have in total (rather than level by level) to distribute in the first place. Feats are less problematic by and large - you'll have a total of 14 general feats. You get one bonus feat at level 1 if your character is human, and other bonus feats dependent on the class(es) you take. Just know what you want and shoehorn them in when you can (always trying not to take pre-epic feats in epic levels). Yes, there are rules with some of them (eg, you can't take save-boosting feats or Toughness as a bonus feat), and you need to know whether a feat has restrictions on it before you try to take it (for example, you won't be able to take Overwhelming Critical with this build: you need Power Attack, Cleave, Great Cleave, Improved Critical and a Strength of at least 23).

The way I build is to sit down and come up with a concept (doesn't have to be a grand one - just something like a nimble attacker from the shadows, or a melee truck who gets up in your face, or even a behind the lines rainer-down of fiery death). Then it's pencil and paper time! Which class(es) will get me what I need? How do I mitigate the inevitable shortfalls (poor saves, dreadful AC, etc)? Which skills will help me - and how many ranks do I need/want? What are the must-have, should-have, could-have feats? Then I try to plot when I should take levels in whichever classes I've decided on for best effect, and so I don't accidentally gimp myself. After that I take my pnp draft and put it here on the Unfinalized Builds forum for people to critique and improve (or point and laugh, as the case may be). Then I'll run it through the Pretty Good Character Creator or Halls of Advanced Training to make sure it's a legal build (that is, that I haven't cocked up my sums). Admittedly, that step has been a recent development for me, but you don't need to hear about it here. Finally, it's play time! Then, after a thorough testing, it can go onto the Full Epic forum - if it's worth it. There are several build concepts I've had that have never reached those rarefied heights because the build didn't live up to what I was hoping for. But no learning is wasted, yes?

Anyway, as I said, I'll try to have a proper look later. That said, I know very little about Cleric and not much more about Assassin.

Cheers

The first thing that strikes me is pre-epic feats. It appears that you're not intending to take Blind Fighting or Knockdown (thus also not Imp Knockdown). I would suggest that those 2 are must-haves (there's very little point casting Darkness over a mob if you can't use it to inflict Death Attacks all over the place), and you should drop the idea of Whirlwind Attack and Imp Expertise for them asap. I would have suggested dropping Mobility as well, so you could take all 3, but we've missed the boat on that one.

In epic levels, you'll be wanting Epic Weapon Focus, Armor Skin and Epic Prowess, leaving you with 4 more general feats for stat increases to go with the 10 attribute bumps you get throughout the build - but don't forget that you'll get a bonus feat at Assassin 14, which you could use for another Great Dex. That could mean a final Dex of 28 (+9) and Wis of 18 (+4). However, I notice you're not planning to take any Cleric-enhancing feats, so am guessing you plan to use the class for buffs more than anything, so a final Wis of 16 should be enough, allowing for another 2 points in Dex (taking it to 30).

Which brings me to my next point, which is about the class spread. Currently, your pre-epic split seems to be Ranger 8/ Cleric 3-5/ Assassin 7-9. Given that keeping pre-epic BAB at 15 or below to maximise the use of Divine Power is another ship that's already sailed, we might as well go for the best BAB we can, which (following the Rule of Four) would be Ranger 8/ Cleric 4/ Assassin 8 - giving a BAB of 17, where R8/C3/A9 and R8/C5/A7 both give 16.

My temptation would be to take 2 levels of Ranger in epic (10 in total): the first at 21 (or thereabouts), and the last at 40 for a final discipline dump (and another Favored Enemy iirc).
